abstracts.cdata!:
The efficiency of the project is high.
            Its appraisal was underpinned with an unusually thorough and
            detailed economic analysis of coral reef degradation in
            Indonesia. The institutional development impact of the
            project was substantial. The project supported the
            Government of Indonesia (GOI's) decision to designate
            the newly created Department of Marine Affairs and Fisheries
            (DKP) as the agency responsible for the equitable and
            sustainable management of coral reef resources, here there
            had been none before. The sustainability of the project is
            not evaluable at this time. Overall, while the economic
            justification for Coral Reef Management Program (COREMAP) is
            robust, not only because of the local benefits but also
            because of the high global benefits of protecting
            Indonesia's coral reef diversity, insufficient
            information is available to judge the resilience to risk of
            the other major factors that need to be considered. The
            Bank's performance was satisfactory. The preparation of
            the project was underpinned by extensive analytical papers
            and surveys, and GOI ownership was strong. The design of the
            project was unusually complex, but responded to the needs of
            the proposed strategy and the lack of a robust institutional
            counterpart. Supervision focused on development impact and
            responded flexibly to drastic changes in institutional and
            country conditions, although donor coordination could have
            been better.
